docs.lead_paragraph: The meeting was supposed to open a dialogue between police officers and city residents, perhaps even repair relations that have grown ever more strained since Amadou Diallo was shot dead last year. But last night, the first in a series of hearings before a City Council committee examining police-community relations instead featured one resident after another relating, with a mixture of passion and anger, humiliating encounters with the police. And few, if any, of the more than 200 people who attended the meeting in the Soundview section of the Bronx, not far from where Mr. Diallo was shot, were in any mood to hear explanations from top police commanders in the borough.

headline.main: In Bronx, Tension at Meeting on Police-Community Relations

docs.abstract: New York State Senate Republican majority leader Joseph L Bruno defends New York City Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's response to fatal police shooting of Patrick M Dorismond; suggests that attacks against Giuliani's handling of shooting are politically motivated (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A judge in Manhattan has rejected a move to dismiss a lawsuit accusing a health maintenance organization of negligence for refusing to pay for drug rehabilitation for a man who later died of an overdose. The suit, against Aetna U.S. Healthcare, is one of the first in New York alleging a wrongful denial of treatment by an H.M.O., said David Trueman, a lawyer for the estate of the dead man, Robert Payton.
docs.abstract: New York State Supreme Court, Manhattan, Justice Herman Cahn rejects move to dismiss lawsuit accusing health maintenance organization Aetna US Healthcare of negligence for refusing to pay for drug rehabilitation for Robert Payton, man who later died of overdose (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: For years, New York City's public hospitals have been known as health care outposts of last resort. If the Health and Hospitals Corporation, which runs them, had advertised their medical services, it would have been considered akin to Albania hawking its tourist attractions: they may exist, but who would want to go there? But now, flush with cash and competing for the same patients that even the city's fanciest private hospitals are suddenly longing for, the city hospital agency has begun the first advertising campaign in its history. The idea, hospital officials say, is not unlike that behind every consumer product these days: they want to turn the public hospitals into a brand.

headline.main: In a Competitive Market, City Runs Ads for Its Hospitals

docs.abstract: Article discusses new television advertising campaign being run for first time in New York City history that promotes medical care and facilities at city operated hospitals; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Unable to find enough workers in the booming economy, American corporations are trying to expand the labor pool. Until recently, employers had met their labor needs by hiring people who were already employed or at least wanted to work. But as this pool shrinks, they are increasingly recruiting from among the 36 million working-age people in the United States who had not sought a job, or even thought about taking one.

headline.main: Companies Try Dipping Deeper Into Labor Pool

docs.abstract: Shrinking labor pool in booming economy prompts American corporations to recruit from among 36 million working-age people in United States who are not seeking a job; this includes urban poor, retirees, homemakers, men and women mustering out of military service, handicapped, women coming off welfare and illegal immigrants not counted in labor force; people with jobs are being recruited to moonlight in second jobs, and college students are being recruited for part-time work; companies are offering flexible hours and many other worker benefits, but not significantly higher pay; photos; charts (M)
docs.snippet: Unable to find enough workers in the booming economy, American corporations are trying to expand the labor pool.    Until recently, employers had met their labor needs by hiring people who were already employed or at least wanted to work. But as this...

docs.lead_paragraph: SIX months after the county sold the Nassau County Medical Center, critics say they are pleased to find that their fears that the private owner would neglect its mission to care for the county's poor have so far proved unfounded. If anything, they say, service has improved since the yoke of county bureaucracy was lifted. Dozens of doctors and nurses have been hired. Hours at the hospital's community clinics have been extended to evenings and weekends. New moneymaking services, like a weight-loss program that includes surgical stomach stapling, have been added.

headline.main: New Doctors, New Services, New Hope; The Company That Brought Nassau's Medical Center Gets Good Marks So Far (but Critics Emphasize 'So Far')

docs.abstract: Report on Nassau County Medical Center in New York after six months of privatized operations; services reportedly have improved without yoke of county bureaucracy, dozens of doctors and nurses have been hired, community clinics have expanded hours and new money-making services, such as weight-loss program, have been added; photos; Jerald C Newman, president of Nassau Health Care Corp, stresses goal of becoming competitive with other health-care institutions (M)
docs.snippet: SIX months after the county sold the Nassau County Medical Center, critics say they are pleased to find that their fears that the private owner would neglect its mission to care for the county's poor have so far proved unfounded.    If anything, they...

docs.lead_paragraph: TWO recent telephone calls about Renaissance Cruises were coincidental, but they led me to a glimmering of a tempest brewing. A classmate wanted to tell me what a wonderful cruise she and her husband had taken in the South Pacific. Several months earlier they had booked a 900-odd-square-foot suite with wraparound balcony on one of the company's five identical new vessels, which carry 684 passengers, all adults. She hates the heat and has back problems, so when they went in February, she skipped the rougher shore excursions. Her vacation seemed a bargain, she said: $5,000 for two, including air fare between Los Angeles and Tahiti. Another classmate called because she and her husband, weary of winter in Wisconsin, were enticed by Renaissance's heavy advertising of 2-for-1 deals in the Pacific. This friend also has health problems, and watches her budget closely. I supported the advice she had been given: not to buy a cruise for next winter without cancellation insurance. But at the moment of the call, big names in the travel-insurance field were dropping off the Renaissance roster.
docs.abstract: Practical Traveler column warns that several travel insurance companies are dropping Renaissance Cruises from coverage because of line's extremely strict cancellation policy; line says stringent rules are tradeoff for good cruises prices (M)
docs.snippet: TWO recent telephone  calls about Renaissance Cruises were coincidental, but they led me to a glimmering of a tempest brewing. A classmate wanted to tell me what a wonderful cruise she and her husband had taken in the South Pacific. Several months...

docs.lead_paragraph: The House passed a Republican budget blueprint early yesterday by a vote of 211 to 207. The nonbinding blueprint sets targets for spending and tax cuts for next year. Republicans said the plan balanced the need to spend more on the military and education with their desire to restrain the growth of government and provide large tax cuts. Democrats said the plan would push the government back into deficit, put Social Security and Medicare at risk and force deep cuts in essential programs.

headline.main: THE REPUBLICAN BLUEPRINT: Details of Plan on Spending and Tax Cuts

docs.abstract: House passes Republican budget blueprint by vote of 211-207; nonbinding plan sets targets for spending and tax cuts for next year; details of blueprint (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''White House Seeks to Curb Pills Used to Calm the Young'' (front page, March 20): The problem is not that parents and psychiatrists are looking for a quick fix for behavioral problems in children but that the cost of therapy may not be fully covered by insurance. Ritalin is far cheaper than therapy. Most parents do not like the idea of having to medicate their children with psychotropic drugs, but they also cannot afford to pay for therapy themselves.

headline.main: In Search of Ways to Heal a Child

docs.abstract: Aja Starke letter on Mar 20 article notes many parents who cannot afford to pay for therapy must chose between leaving psychological disorders untreated or giving children Ritalin to ease symptoms; drawing

docs.lead_paragraph: With the House and the Senate deadlocked on legislation to define patients' rights, an influential Congressman proposed a compromise today on one of the biggest issues in dispute: how many Americans should be protected by new federal standards? The proposal came from Representative Charlie Norwood, co-author of the bill passed by the House last October.

headline.main: Compromise Proposed on Patients' Rights Bill
